questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented to the neurology outpatient department with resting tremors, slow movements, and rigidity. Upon further evaluation by the doctor, he was noted to have a stooped posture and also drew very small objects when asked to draw. The condition involves the structure marked in red in the given image. Identify the region of the brain from which this structure originates?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mesenchephalon In the given question, the clinical picture of the patient as bradykinesia, tremor and rigidity with stooped posture and micrographia on examination points towards the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease. It is due to decrease in the dopaminergic neurons of substantia nigra in the midbrain. As asked in the question about the o rigin of midbrain it is mesenchephalon. Hence the answer is option A. Other options-

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Metencephalon- it gives origin to pons and cerebellum. Also the cavity forms 4th ventricle. Option C. Myelencephalon- it gives rise to medulla Option D. Prosencephalon- it is divided into telencephalon and diencephalon which gives rise to cerebrum and thalamus and hypothalamus respectively. Also the cavity of both of them give rise to lateral ventricle and third ventricle respectively.

questions.text: A 27 year old female was referred from OBG department for the management of infertility ,galactorrhea and amenorrhea, after all her infertility profile done was normal except serum prolactin levels which were raised. Which of the following coloured arrow marked structure on the MRI represents the origin of this pathology?
questions.correct_answer: C. Structure marked with white arrow
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Structure marked with white arrow In the given clinical scenario, the female presentation suggests her to be a case of prolactin adenoma with clinical features of galactorrhea, infertility and amenorrhea with raised s. Prolactin levels. Prolactin adenoma originates from the pituitary gland. In the given image, the structure marked With white arrow suggest pituitary gland

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Structure marked with blue arrow represents pineal gland. Option B. Structure with orange arrow represents the 4th ventricle. Option D. structure marked with green arrow represents corpus callosum.

questions.text: During your radiology postings in 6th semester, while your consultant is teaching you about the various structures at different level of brain, he showed you the following image and tells you about the marked structure with yellow arrow originate from hippocampus and terminates on mammillary bodies. Which of the following option is correct regarding the type of fibers present in this structure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and B In the given question, the marked structure which originates from hippocampus and goes to the mammillary body is called fornix . It plays an important role in the limbic system. It contains majorly association fibers but the commissural part of this , known as hippocampal commissure contains commissural fibers. Hence the most appropriate answer for this question will be option D.

Highyeild:

Association fibers of the brain, also known as association tracts of the brain or intrahemispheric tracts (cortex-cortex connections ) are a type of white matter tract that connects different areas in the same hemisphere. There are two types of association fibers : long-range and U-fibers

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Comissural fibers Option B. Association fibers Option C. Projection fibers Projection fibers includes corona radiata , internal capsule etc.

Extraedge:

DTI tractography can identify the following long range tracts arcuate fasciculus (connections between the Broca, Geschwind and Wernicke areas : contains long-range and short-range fibers that connect the frontal, parietal and temporal lobes superior and inferior fronto-occipital fasciculi cingulum (limbic system fibers) uncinate fasciculus superior and inferior longitudinal fasciculi

questions.text: During the clinical rounds in your ward, your consultant asks you about the content of the following structure marked with blue arrow. Your answer will be –
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Basilar artery In the given question, the image given below shows the section of the brain showing pons surrounded by peripontine cistern as the marked structure., the content is basilar artery. Hence the correct option is option B.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. PICA is content of cisterna magna. Option C. Great cerebral vein is the content of quadrigeminal cistern.

questions.text: A 36 year old male presented to OPD with complaint of chest discomfort, cough and for 2 months. He also complained of on and off fever and weight loss of more than 5kgs. His chest X Ray was normal. So CT-scan was done. Your junior resident asks you about the vertebral level at which the image was taken. Your answer would be-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T2-T3 In the given clinical scenario, the question though discuss the pathology related to the respiratory system but the question asks you can clearly see the anatomy of the blood vessel seen in the CT of the chest. As all the branches of aorta are visible , so the section must have been taken from above T4 as it marks the arch of aorta. Hence , the appropriate answer for this question will be option A

Highyeild:

The thoracic aorta is the most superior division of the aorta and is divided into three sections: ascending aorta aortic arch descending aorta The thoracic aorta begins at the aortic valve, located obliquely just to the left of the midline at the level of the third intercostal space. It terminates as it exits the thorax to enter the abdomen through the median arcuate ligament between the diaphragmatic crurae anterior to the T12 vertebral body.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. at T4-T5 level , arch of aorta will be visible along with subclavian vein. Option C. at T5-T6 level, descending aorta will be visible and not the branches of the aorta. Option D. at C7-T1 level, we wont be able to see the branches of the aorta.

Extraedge:

Thoracic aorta. The thoracic aorta begins at the level of the T4 vertebra and courses downwards through the posterior mediastinum. Initially, it is found left to the vertebral column, but as it descends it inclines towards the midline and ends up being anterior to the lower border of the body of T12 vertebra.

questions.text: You were in neurology OPD during you medicine rotation where you observed patients with different movement disorder. Which of the following marked structure represent the incorrect match with the condition associated?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Purple colour- hemiballismus In the given question, as marked, the following structure represents- red colour structure- caudate nucleus yellow colour- globus pallidus blue colour- putamen . blue and yellow marked areas are together called as lentiform nucles purple colour- thalamus.

Highyeild:

Involuntary movements in basal ganglia diseases include ① tremor, ② chorea, ③ ballism, ④ athetosis, and ⑤ dystonia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Hence the lesion in all these will be- Caudate and putamen(also called as neostriatum together )- chorea(option A and C are correct) Globus pallidus- athetosis. (option B is also correct) Subthalamic nuclei (and not thalamus ) leads to hemiballismus. Hence the incorrect match as asked in the question is option D.

Extraedge:

The basal ganglia is a collective group of structures in the brain. These include the striatum, (composed of the putamen and caudate nucleus), globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and the subthalamic nucleus. Along with other structures, the basal ganglia are part of a neural circuit that is integral to voluntary motor function. It was once believed that the primary function of the basal ganglia was to integrate projections from the cerebral cortex, and project information via the thalamus to the motor cortex.

questions.text: You are final year MBBS student studying about the chambers of heart. You came across a radiological image showing the following chambers of heart as given below. Which of the following statement is true regarding the following?

options.label: A
options.text: The anterior most chamber of heart is marked as RA.

options.label: B
options.text: The right border of the heart is formed by structure marked as RV.

options.label: C
options.text: The posterior most chamber is marked as LA.

options.label: D
options.text: The left border of the heart is formed majorly by structure marked as LA.

questions.correct_answer: C. The posterior most chamber is marked as LA.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The posterior most chamber is marked as LA. In the given image, we are able to see 5 different structures labelled as- RV- right ventricle RA- right atrium. LA-left atrium LV-left ventricle Ao- aorta. The posterior most chamber of the heart is formed by LA as shown in the above image, hence it is correct answer.

Highyeild:

There are four heart chambers , the right atrium, left atrium, right ventricle and left ventricle. These receive blood from the body and lungs and contract to transmit blood to the lungs for oxygenation and to the body for use in metabolism.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - The anterior most chamber if the heart is RV and nor RA, hence option A is incorrect. The right border of the heart is formed by RA and not RV, hence option B is also incorrect. The left border of the heart is majorly formed by LV and not LA. So option D is also an incorrect statement.

Extraedge:

It is best to list the four chambers in order of the series that blood travels through the heart: venous blood returning from the body drains into the right atrium via the SVC, IVC and coronary sinus the right atrium pumps blood through the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle the right ventricle pumps blood through the pulmonary semilunar valve into the pulmonary trunk to be oxygenated in the lungs blood returning from the lungs drains into the left atrium via the four pulmonary veins the left atrium pumps blood through the bicuspid (mitral) valve into the left ventricle the left ventricle pumps blood through the aortic semilunar valve into the ascending aorta to supply the body

questions.text: You were given the following spotter during your final professional examination for identifying the structures present in the floor of the third ventricle. The following structures are marked as 1,2,3,4. Which of the following number represents the termination point of the fornix and a part of limbic system?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4 In the given question, to identify the structure on the radiological image, we should know about the anatomy of the floor of the third ventricle . The structure labelled are as follows- Optic chiasma Pituitary infundibulum Tuber cinereum Mammillary body. Hence, as asked in the question the structure where the fornix ends and also is a part of limbic system is mammillary body which is marked by 4. So, the correct answer for this question is option D.

Highyeild:

The floor of the third ventricle is located medial to the uncus and anterior perforated substance and above the midbrai n. From anterior to posterior, the floor includes the lower margin of the optic chiasm, the pituitary stalk surrounded by the tuber cinereum, mamillary bodies, and the midbrain .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. 2 - Pituitary infundibulum Option B. 3 - Tuber cinereum Option C. 1 -Optic chiasma

Extraedge:

The third ventricle present in the diencephalon is called the diocoel. The fourth ventricle present between the brainstem and cerebellum is called the metacoel. The cavity of the spinal cord is called the central canal or the neurocoel

questions.text: A 60 year old male presented with progressive right side sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, unsteadiness and inability to balance. On examination, there is decreased sensation on the posterior side of the external auditory meatus. Her Rinnie’s test was positive on both the side., PTA revealed SNHL on the right side. MRI was done which showed the following appearance. Which of the following structure is the origin for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

8th cranial nerve In the given clinical scenario, features like progressive right side sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, unsteadiness and inability to balance points towards involvement of vestibular components. On examination, there is decreased sensation on the posterior side of the external auditory meatus which is also known as hitzelberg’s sign Her rinne’s test was positive on both the side., PTA revealed SNHL on the right side with MRI showing appearance of ice-cream cone appearance p oints towards the diagnosis of Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma which arises form 8th nerve at the CP angle. Hence, the correct answer is option B.

Highyeild:

The main treatment for schwannoma is surgery to remove the tumour. The type of surgery you have depends on where in the body the tumour is. For small vestibular schwannomas, you may have stereotactic radiotherapy or radiosurgery. Both treatments target high doses of radiotherapy to the tumour.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. 7Th nerve involved by the tumor does not originate from it. Option C. Cerebellum can be involved in this in later courses due to metastasis but is very rare and usually does not involve it. Option D. external auditory meatus is not involved in this tumor. Hence it is not the correct answer.

Extraedge:

A schwannoma (or neurilemmoma ) is a usually benign nerve sheath tumor composed of Schwann cells, which normally produce the insulating myelin sheath covering peripheral nerves. Schwannomas are homogeneous tumors, consisting only of Schwann cells. The tumor cells always stay on the outside of the nerve, but the tumor itself may either push the nerve aside and/or up against a bony structure (thereby possibly causing damage). Schwannomas are relatively slow-growing. For reasons not yet understood, schwannomas are mostly benign and less than 1% become malignant, degenerating into a form of cancer known as neurofibrosarcoma.
